action.action-desc: Mr. Ellison introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To authorize the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to award grants for municipal solid waste prevention and recycling program development, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Zero Waste Development and Expansion Act.

The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (in this Act referred to as the Administrator) shall award grants to local governments or consortia of local governments, which may be acting in coordination with one or more nongovernmental entities. The grants shall be used to develop solid waste prevention and recycling tactics and operations, which may include—

paragraph.text: development or deployment of technologies or practices to increase rates of waste prevention, recycling, composting, or product reuse;
capital investment in infrastructure to start or expand waste prevention, recycling, composting, or product reuse programs;
partnerships with local businesses interested in incorporating new technologies or processes to reduce or prevent waste in production or packaging; or
community outreach and public education programming, including programming to—

subparagraph.text: increase community knowledge of effective waste prevention, recycling, composting, or product reuse practices; and
increase behavior that will reduce overall household waste generation.

subsection.text: Grants shall be awarded under this Act to applicants that collectively represent a range of existing waste prevention, recycling, composting, and product reuse rates. In order to be considered for this award, applicants must—

paragraph.text: set specific waste prevention, recycling, composting, product reuse, or public education goals that will bring communities closer to zero waste;
have a clearly established plan to use grant funds for one or more of the purposes described in section 2; and
meet other criteria as determined by the Administrator.

subsection.text: Additional weight may be given to the applications of local governments or consortia that—

paragraph.text: have statutorily committed to zero waste principles;
address the disproportionate environmental, health, and economic burden of waste disposal that is borne by communities of color and low income;
propose to use funds for waste prevention or recycling programs in schools;
employ adaptive management practices to identify and address unintended consequences as they arise, including potential contamination of land, water, air, or food;
have a demonstrated need for additional investment in infrastructure and programs to achieve waste prevention or recycling;
will drive technologies for product reuse, recycling, composting, or waste prevention;
demonstrate ways in which the grant will encourage further investment in waste prevention, recycling, composting, or product reuse projects; or
incorporate multistakeholder involvement, including nonprofit, commercial, and public sector partners.

section.text: Grant awardees shall report to the Administrator the results of their project and relevant data requested by the Administrator to track the grant program’s impact.

The Administrator shall convene or co-convene an annual conference for current, past, and potential grantees, and other stakeholders, to learn from each other’s experiences in moving toward a zero waste goal.
In this Act, the term recycling means a series of activities by which material that has reached the end of its current use is processed into material utilized in the production of new products.
There are authorized to be appropriated to the Administrator $100,000,000 for the period encompassing fiscal years 2016 through 2021 for carrying out this Act.
